threads.com: Why isn't there any digital painting software that can accurately emulate traditional painting yet?The ones that try all look like shit. What are the technological bottlenecks? We're not really closer today than we were 10 years ago. Maybe with the exception for Rebelles pigment mixing, but the actual brush tools haven't improved in a decade+ since dual brush and the mixer brush were introduced in PS. 3d graphics and other CGI production tools are improving at breakneck speeds but digital painting is completely stagnated. Why?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392576
Rebelle has pigment mixing and some cool bleed effects but that’s about it. Same stamp based legacy brushes as the rest. It doesn’t look very convincing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392527
I’ve probaby done close to 10k custom brushes. I know you can get sort of, kind of, close, but only if you don’t get too painterly. No amount of brush tweaking in Photoshop can make you do these marks because the brush engine’s limits. It’s not about effort you daft cunt. Adobe wetbrush might be the closest we’ve gotten but only brief glimpses of that technology has been shown.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392021
There are a lot of reasons.
First off, there's the fact that when working in trad you're manipulating 3-D materials. Trad media are physical things. Mimicking simpler media like graphite, charcoal, ink, marker, and even watercolor to an extent isn't so hard, since the pigments or dyes are only applied in a relatively thin layer on the drawing surface and their interactions are fairly simple to emulate with some exceptions (which I'll get to shortly). However, when you're getting into anything that has to do with applying pigment with a bristle brush, especially paints that you can layer and apply thick globs of to the canvas, and of which its properties change when wet or dry, a 2D pixel-manipulation-based engine probably isn't going to cut it. Paint is a 3D medium, a physical fluid, and for truly accurate emulation, would most likely need to be simulated and modeled in 3D. The pigment mixing you mentioned is only a small step in that direction, and very few programs support that- to my knowledge, only Rebelle 5, MyPaint, and an obscure paint app for iOS devices (developed by the same guy responsible for the pigment mixing algorithm in MyPaint) even have this feature.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392682
(Cont'd) Furthermore, the very hardware that we use to interface with digital art programs are flawed to begin with. Putting aside the fact that we're interacting with a flat, textureless 2D screen, our only tool for drawing and painting is a pen with a plastic nib. How can you adequately emulate a brush, laden with ink or paint, with that? You really can't.
Digital mimicking traditional is a niche thing. The old stamp brush paradigm ain't broke, so few people care to fix it. Most are fine with digital painting being its own flavor and don't feel the need for it to really emulate traditional. However, digital pigment mixing does seem like a very good step forward which has been received very well by all who have tried it, since it allows for intuitive on-canvas mixing that results in much more rich and vibrant colors. Hopefully we'll see it become a standard feature in other digital painting programs in the future, especially in the FOSS software space.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6390881
Read through every figure drawing book you can, so long as the book is illustrated with the author's own work, and the author's work is actually good*. Some older books are very wordy; you should still read them. The written word is another way of taking in information, distinct from looking at pictures, watching videos, listening to lectures, and actually practicing drawing. Besides, the older artists/authors tend to be of a much higher caliber than later ones. Some recommendations: John H. Vanderpoel ("The Human Figure"), Richard G. Hatton ("Figure Drawing"), Frank Howard ("Science of Drawing, Part III - The Human Figure," no longer in print but scans are available free on Google Books).
You won't understand or appreciate everything your first time reading, but you'll have that information in the back of your mind. Once you've had more experience, you'll be able to get more out of those passages, and things that previously seemed unimportant or unintelligible will finally "click." This is a lifelong pursuit.
*The only exception I'll make here is "Drawing Lessons from the Great Masters" by Robert Beverly Hale, which is illustrated with master drawings. This is actually a good book to start with for an overview of some very important principles.

threads.com:
I've been trying to set up a lineart brush but I can't seem to get it to work how I want to. I tried watching tutorials about it, and as far as I can tell I am doing things right, but the issue persists, which is that the line stroke starts nice and thin, getting bigger as I increase pressure, but as I end the stroke and reduce pressure, the line at the end of the stroke is a much more abrupt end and doesn't trail of as thin as it began.

Perhaps I am expecting to be able to do everything with one brush in a program, or maybe its a matter of hardware and my tablet is better at registering a gentle touch at the start of a stroke rather than the end, but I am very used to drawing with physical mediums, and what I want to do with a brush in krita is quick hatching strokes that start thick and taper off - the kind you'd see in some old school illustrations.
I can kind of do it, but like in pic related the strokes end up going 'backwards' to how I am used to drawing them on paper, and I am forced to do them slowly...plz help.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392165
Check the pressure sensitivity on your device and Krita. That curve should give a feel for max pressure. You're not reducing pressure mid stroke so focus on not hitting the peak of the curve. The blob means you're pressing hard all the way through.

last_replies.com:

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
i don't care for them because it's based on technique for the most part. but even when the aren't as obvious in the technique, they are just daily lives of french. i have as much care for art that is deliberately about its current time period, much more than any other artistic school than any other, as i do about what some south east asian fisherman was doing at any given time. there are some interesting trivia to be learned, but hardly the foundation of great art.
they took the maxim of contemporaneity, that art is about expression of the current time, too closely and with too much awareness. this makes their art much more limited in intellectual scope. whereas art of the old master tended to be more inspired by literature, history, and ideas beyond the current circumstances even when they wove with the times, with erudite use of symbols and iconography.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Would you look at it for longer than one second?
threads.com:
No matter how much skill you got, how many years, decades of experience, how long you spend drawing it, how many hours, days, weeks, how unique your designs are, how personal it is for you or even how generic and trendy you made it, people won't fucking look at it for longer than one second.
Neat. Swipe. Like. Click away. Bookmark. NEXT!
You would do the same.
Everyone is an artist and art is everywhere. Infinite supply makes the value of a single piece nearly worthless. People spend more time reading the text in the balloons than looking at the art in the comic. More time reading the tweet than looking at the image embedded in the tweet. Even the most successful professionals only get a tiny bit more attention per person per drawing than a teenager who picked up the pencil yesterday and posted a stick figure.
Anyone else feels the same way?
I used to draw lots for fun, but when I think if I posted something on the internet it wouldn't captivate a single person, drawing feels meaningless. What is the point? Upload this and it's just a waste of space in someone's servers. A waste of data and of time.
In thousands of illustrations I have seen only a handful made me stop and look for longer than one second. This is my goal now. I'll study them to figure out what they did different and maybe I'll realize something and be able to do the same. If I can make people stop clicking and pause just to stare what I drew, I'll know I've made it.
I guess this makes me an attention whore. Maybe sovl comes from drawing what you want and not from caring about what other people think. But then what if "what I want" is to make others feel the same way I was made feel those handful of times?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6389504
>everything has been spread so thinly, everything is so saturated
based low iq pseud spamming figure of speech word salad that doesn't make any sense

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
OP, if you think 100 people looking at your art for 1 second is not worth it, draw something as a gift for someone and have 1 person look at it for 100 seconds. See how that feels.

Drawing fanart is actually a good way to have people looking at it for longer, because if someone cares about a character - especially a niche one -, he will admire the piece for a while longer, trying to increase the amount of time he can spend consooming the character. But if you don't like doing it, that is not way to live.

I have the same worries as you, thinking everything is too quick to consume, while knowing I'm also guilty of it.
But I know a handful of people who actually stare into details and enjoy them.

However, I do still like drawing for myself, that is something you should practice. Pleasing others BECAUSE you have pleased yourself is the best way to never feel disappointed.
I also want to please my characters, give them a world to exist in, and that is good motivation to me.

Last, but not least, learn to appreciate little details in life.
Drawing something relatable is powerful, it can be something funny, or something comfy, or something nostalgic. All you need to do it to FEEL that connection to some visual element yourself and know that someone out there will also feel it.

Here's something I drew on such impulse. I'm a nobody, back then I had maybe 10 followers, yet I got 5 likes and a comment about "OMG I member this". Pretty good ROI, if you ask me.

tl;dr: You have to learn to stop and admire things if you wish your art to evoke the same effect on people. Contemplate more, draw what draws you in.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

threads.com:
I am currently in the process in designing a fantasy world. I started yesterday on laying out the map. While I found a lot of good guides online, they mainly focus on the very abstract, high-level stuff like mountain ranges, great rivers, barrier forrests and capital cities. This is all good, and helped me create my continent map, but I want to go down to the local, regional level.

Currently, the regions are all basically plain white spaces, with occasional great river cutting across. I KNOW that in reality, this would be full of local streams, small rivers, hundreds of lakes, hamlets, roads, hills etc. But I don't really know how to start placing them all. I guess I start with an enchanced view of a region, taking a new A4 page and drawing its borders in it, but then what? I have zero clue how streams or rivers occur naturally. How swamps occur. Where would villages form (and no, I know from real life they don't all form next to a river).

my experience is twofold. i prefer interacting with people who do art mostly as a hobby, they're usually very welcoming and friendly and nice to do art with or exchange over annoying things or even the occasional insecurity.

on the other hand, many people working in the field or looking for job opportunities tend to be mostly interested in what they can get "out of you", and those drop you quickly if you are no use to them career-wise. but even among pros many are pretty laid back and good to talk to and will take their time to help you with stuff or give feedback.
just keep your heart open, and you'll find a good niche.

threads.com: How does one paint values in the shadow area? What principle do values adhere to in diffused light?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392260
>Value groups are a part of keying your painting.
>You don't need to do any of this,
Traditional painters did because they had to mix their colors in advance and had to make sure the painting would read well.

If your painting reads fine then you don't need to worry about value groups.


>I've just found that this method of value study gives good insight to beginners very fast.
Good for you if starting by finding the two most extreme values works for you. Your goal should be not needing to do that though.

It is a little like if you do line work and then need to start by placing down the thickest and thinnest line first. I mean, sure. If that works for you.

Painting (and drawing) should be a fluid process where you just have fun. You will want to eliminate as many mechanical processes from that experience as possible. A single value stroke or added highlight near the end is often enough to change how an entire image reads.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I'm currently using cadmium red, cadmium yellow pale and ultramarine blue (plus burnt umber) on my palette mostly for portraits but also some landscapes. But I find the intensity of these colours is too saturated for every application and so have to spend time mixing them down... not to mention the cost of cadmium colors.

Is there a low chroma alternative for these colors which will cover all the bases without the added cost and labor?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
white either lead or titanium, no zinc
yellow ocher
raw sienna
burnt sienna (brownish red in mass tone, a bright brick color in glazes)
red earths of your choice
raw umber
carbon black of our choice

optional low cost pigments
nicosia green earth (appears somewhat a greenish blue with white, translucent)
violet ochre/violet hematite (subtle violet tints)

Reserve cadmium colors and ultramarine for when you need something saturated. Using high cost saturated pigments only to make them gray or brown is a waste in my expert and poorfag opinion.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6391185

NTA but prussian blue is a really, really strong tinter, so i don't think that works if you're looking for low chroma colors.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6391185
synthetic ultramarine blue is cheap enough that you don't need much other unless you are doing historical pigments. yes, prussian blue is highly tinting and there's not much uses for it unless you use that specific color in your paintings a lot or you use it in strange mixes.
if you don't need a blueish green you can also drop nicosia green earth. if you need a green and don't want to buy the more expensive synthetic green pigments like cadmium, cobalt, chromium or viridian, there are other green earths. some lower chroma olive green, and some that are bright and more yellow, depending on where they are from and manufacturer
choice also depends on if you care about things like transparency and opacity.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

>>6389248
>also funny thing, i used to think that 104% srgb was a good thing (higher number good!). then i realized it's just a wildly inaccurate SRGB. same with wide gamut.
Not necessarily, as I wrote above it depends what you want to display your data on. If you're intending the data for different devices with larger gamut sRGB can be a severe limitation.
If the gamut of the work-monitor is larger than the gamut of the intended display-device on the other hand you will simply have to have the correct .icc monitor profile installed in order for the software to know how to display the data. The example of 104% sRGB is however a point where a 100% clean sRGB would make more sense as the gain is little and you're introducing a lot more variables.

>CSP is getting a new version soon, maybe they'll adress this?
Unlikely, it's a problem we had before budget-workstations were overclocked dual Celeron 300A s .. one core per CPU, and mainstream multi-core CPUs have been around since 2006. If the lack of the multi-threaded smudge-tool has not been addressed for 20 years it's unlikely to suddenly happen next month.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6382214
painting ugly (upclose)
> Some artists seem to render subjects very accurately but still not achieve this effect?

This is because they try to paint every little detail which is not how your eyes/brain actually sees and processes the world.

If you've ever seen a sargent painting in real life, when you stand at a distance it looks incredible. But when you get upclose the illusion stops working and it looks almost abstract from how loose and undefined the brush strokes are.

so basically
>don't try to "fix" WHILE you are putting in your colors, do that after.
>use a color checker (you would be surprised how unsaturated and dark colors actually are in real life)

another reason might be that by not adding needless detail, your brain fills in the blanks which is closer to what happens you look at things IRL, so its more interesting to look at.

THE BIGGEST REASON VERY IMPORTANT:

Your brain is wired to love abstraction, because nature is abstract. When you look at a beautiful tree, you arent paying attention to the detail on every single leaf all at once.
The tree does not plan its leaves out in the same exact way everytime.

Zoom into pic related, you will see how much of it looks pretty much like random crap, but its still pleasing to look at.
This painting looks so real, but the detail is just not there in most areas.

If you zoom into the best realist paintings, I can guarantee every spot you choose could look like its own abstract painting

Anon my man, I know you can fucking do it. I was in the same kind of boat myself for a time.

For the longest time, I myself wanted to learn to draw, like my older brother, but I always gave up and overtime believed I couldn't draw or learn it, and it wasn't "my thing" since I always just played videogames for my hobby when I was younger, and when I got motivation even for a moment to learn, I always lost it because learning new things is hard, and drawing is, especially starting out without any direction, really fucking hard.
Now after about 2 years when I finally got down to it due to some life stuff, I can say I am at least somehow decent. Not really "that good", but compared to 2 years ago, it's night and day.
So just keep at it, keep being dedicated but slow down when you need to, be kind to yourself, and make failure your friend you can learn from.
What >>6380965 said is also true, don't attach your self-worth to your art too much, or any skill for that matter. It can destroy you, and it's super easy to think things like that without knowing, and if Art really doesn't work out full-time, it can't hurt to keep it as a nice hobby. But don't be afraid to stop/ take a break too if you really stop enjoying making art, and it's hurting you in any shape or form.

And also, As a fellow guy who lost their mother way too early, sorry about your mom.

Yes, many old masters were very hardworking and talented, but they usually possessed the means to pursue art at a VERY young age. By the time they were middle aged they had been masters for decades and could easily convince college kids to do grunt work.
One of the biggest modern examples would be Jeff Koons. I don't give a shit what you think about his art, I'm just drawing parallels to production processes.

threads.com:
It has been 5 months or 6 since AI became a thing in everyone's mouth with DALL-E mini and personally (as someone who consooms art and is not an artist) I haven't noticed a lot of changes in the art community, even when AIs like StableDiffusion have fixed most of its problems in less than 2 months.
Every artist I follow keeps receiving commissions and closing in minutes, they keep earning thousands on Patreon and the engagement has been pretty much the same as how things were a year ago, if not better.
I have noticed most artists I follow started to only post their work on Twitter while abandoning pages like Pixiv, FurAffinity, eHentai and other ones we all know due to the immense amount of spam that's in there, heck, even I as a consoomer I stopped using Pixiv, it became an unsearchble sea of untagged mess and I can't fucking jerk off anymore without digging like crazy for 5+ minutes in order to find the shit I actually like and not a sea of deformed victorian smug sluts.

If you ask me I feel AI is not going to affect freelancing in a lot of ways, however, when it comes to work in the industry I can say I've already seen some changes, like the use of AI for voice acting or AI used to design prints for shirts to be massproduced.
How do you see things? We're close to the end of the year.
